Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: Management needs firm estimates for the quarterly roadmap and is awaiting their input
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open and spreadsheets glowing, when my granddaughter wandered in, her face a mix of hope and uncertainty. “Grandpa, how did you know what you wanted to do with your life?” she asked, her voice barely above a whisper. I could see she needed more than a quick answer—she wanted the kind of wisdom only years could provide. At the same time, my phone buzzed insistently. Management was waiting for my project estimates, and the deadline was now. They needed precision, numbers, and my undivided attention to keep the roadmap on track. My mind raced, torn between the urge to close the laptop and give my granddaughter the guidance she sought, and the pressure to deliver the data my team depended on. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my presence, each unwilling to wait. My heart ached as I looked from her expectant eyes to the blinking cursor on my screen, caught in the impossible space between being the grandparent she needed and the engineer my colleagues relied on.
